Award.AwardTitle: Engineering Technology Degree Creation and Equipment Support

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
A goal of the Tribal Colleges and Universities Program (TCUP) is to increase the science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) instructional and research capacities of specific institutions of higher education that serve the Nation's indigenous students. Expanding the STEM curricular offerings at these institutions expands the opportunities for their students to pursue challenging, rewarding careers in STEM fields, provides for research studies in areas that may be culturally significant, and encourages a community and generational appreciation for science and mathematics education. This project aligns directly with that goal, and moreover will enhance the Nation's knowledge of the impact of providing relevant STEM instruction, on recruiting and retaining underrepresented individuals into STEM studies, and preparing the next generation of STEM professionals. For those students entering the workforce directly from the college, it is important that they have a well-defined skill set in mathematics, science, and technology for entry into the STEM workforce.

Navajo Technical University will develop a two-year engineering technology degree to complement their four-year engineering and digital manufacturing programs. The two-year degree will create a milestone that will encourage students to start a STEM degree while opening a pathway to a bachelor's degree. The project will increase faculty skills in relevant technologies and create a model for incorporating advanced manufacturing technology in engineering education, particularly at tribal colleges and universities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Numerous activities were implemented by Navajo Technical University (NTU) during the past three years to help the TSIP Engineering Technology Degree Creation and Equipment Support Project meet its goals and objectives. As part of the TSIP Project NTU: (1) created a two-year Engineering Technology degree at NTU; (2) engaged Native American students in hands-on projects and research through NTU courses, internships and a summer enrichment program to increase visibility and interest in the NTU engineering program; (3) increased NTU faculty and lab staff skills in advanced manufacturing technology; and (4) worked with other tribal colleges and universities (TCUs) to incorporate advanced manufacturing technology to teach engineering. Positive outputs and outcomes were identified through various data collection tools such as project tracking logs, document reviews, and surveys conducted with students in NTU engineering courses, NTU student interns, NTU engineering faculty, and tribal college and university (TCU) partners. A high-level summary of project accomplishments and findings is provided below.

 

In order to develop the new two-year Engineering Technology degree, NTU created and formalized partnerships with companies and agencies that utilize advanced manufacturing technology and software, purchased advanced manufacturing equipment, revised courses to build a hands-on, project-based two-year curriculum, and obtained approval for the two-year Engineering Technology curriculum. NTU began full implementation of the new two-year Engineering Technology degree in the Fall of 2018 and it now serves as a feeder program for their four-year Industrial Engineering, Mechanical Engineering, and Digital Manufacturing programs. The two-year degree was also expanded into additional concentrations in metrology, metal additive manufacturing and machining during the final year of the project. The new program and concentrations focus on the delivery of a quality project/problem-based curriculum to better prepare students in Engineering Technology. 

 

NTU students participating in engineering courses indicated positive outcomes related to the project. For example, Student Course Survey respondents indicated increased understanding of the purpose and benefits of advanced manufacturing equipment, increased understanding of how advanced manufacturing equipment is used in the field, increased knowledge of equipment available through NTU’s lab, and increased ability to operate advanced manufacturing equipment. NTU students participating in internships also reported positive outcomes related to their involvement with the project. Student Intern Impact Survey respondents indicated increased knowledge, skills and abilities to operate advanced manufacturing equipment, increased understanding of advanced manufacturing concepts and uses in the field, and increased opportunities for future internships and employment. The interns will be using their knowledge and skills to support the ongoing implementation of the two-year program and related concentrations moving forward. 

 

Related to increasing faculty skills in technology, the project provided training on equipment and supported cross course and cross discipline collaborations. Faculty Survey respondents indicated changes in knowledge, skills and/or abilities resulting from their involvement with the Engineering Technology degree program. NTU Faculty Survey respondents indicated increased knowledge of the advanced manufacturing equipment available through NTU's lab, increased ability to explain the benefits and limitations of the equipment to students, increased understanding of how the equipment is used in the field, increased ability to incorporate student projects/research into NTU courses using the equipment, and increased ability to teach students using culturally relevant methods.

 

Related to working with other TCUs to incorporate technology to teach engineering, the TSIP project shared lessons learned with other TCUs, developed project examples and culturally relevant models for other TCUs to use, and created mechanisms to provide services to other TCUs. TCU Partner Survey respondents indicated positive outcomes related to increased advanced manufacturing/engineering technology training and/or resources, increased access to new or different technologies, increased infrastructure in advanced manufacturing/engineering, and increased knowledge, skills and/or abilities for describing and operating advanced manufacturing equipment, as a result of their involvement with the NTU. the TCU partners also indicated that their colleges/universities would be interested in participating in additional NTU advanced manufacturing/engineering technology activities in the future.

 

In order to sustain the successes of the TSIP Engineering Technology Degree Creation and Equipment Support Project, NTU has institutionalized support to continue to implement the new two-year degree program and expanded concentrations. NTU will also continue to engage students in training, projects and research activities as they develop their new NTU Advanced Manufacturing Center. The new Center will not only create local internships and jobs, and provide hands-on opportunities for Native American students to support NTU’s engineering programs, but it will also help the economic development of the Navajo Nation.
